body:
> sudo apt install python3-pip
> sudo pip3 install --upgrade pip # get PIP 21
> sudo pip3 install TTS

When I tried this on my Ubuntu 20.04 system, it downloaded and installed successfully, but I received this message at the end:

`WARNING: Running pip as the 'root' user can result in broken permissions and conflicting behaviour with the system package manager. It is recommended to use a virtual environment instead: https://pip.pypa.io/warnings/venv`

I'm not sure why it was saying "No space left on device" in this case, maybe it's referring to /tmp? But that was running pip3 as --user.

I think the best way forward is to try to install in a virtualenv as the initial warning mentioned.

I removed all the packages that were installed with the `sudo pip3 install TTS` method and instead created an venv, but I'm still getting the same "No space left on device" error when building unidic-lite...

```
cd .local/
python3 -m venv mozilla-tts
cd mozilla-tts
source bin/activate.fish
python3 -m pip install TTS
```

Okay, one last comment on how to get it to install on my Ubuntu 20.04 system. 

Installing tts to a venv requires /tmp having **more** than 4GB, which is what my system has allocated to it. So when I bumped /tmp up to 8GB, it worked: `sudo mount -o remount,size=8G /tmp/` . That fixes the "No space left on device" errors.

Installing tts to ~/.local/bin with a conflicting python3-numpy package installed on my system meant that I had to issue a `pip install --upgrade numpy` to install a newer NumPy to ~/.local/bin, which ~/.local/bin/tts will use.

This has been automatically closed, but the issue has not been fixed.

 On the README.md main page, there is this:

> Install TTS
> TTS supports python >= 3.6, <3.9.
> 
> If you are only interested in [synthesizing speech](https://github.com/mozilla/TTS/tree/dev#example-synthesizing-speech-on-terminal-using-the-released-models) with the released TTS models, installing from PyPI is the easiest option.
> 
> pip install TTS

But that installation instruction will fail for some people. It should say:

> Ubuntu 20.04 instructions:
> 
> cd .local/
> python3 -m venv mozilla-tts
> cd mozilla-tts
> source bin/activate
> python3 -m pip install --upgrade TTS numpy
> 
> Numpy should be installed from PIP instead of using the system python3-numpy package from Debian/Ubuntu 20.04. Installing tts to a venv requires /tmp having more than 4GB, or installation will encounter "No space left on device" errors. To bump /tmp up to 8GB, do this: sudo mount -o remount,size=8G /tmp/
>
